Award.AwardTitle: An Efficient Model for Flows of Large Number of Particles at Moderate to High Reynolds Numbers and Its Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal develops a computational model for simulating numerous interactive particles in a fluid at various Reynolds numbers (Re). This model is novel in the computational efficiency and accuracy. It assimilates interdisciplinary knowledge and strengths of Eulerian and Lagrangian approaches. It uses one fixed mesh to resolve the fluid field with spectral accuracy and to track all particles in a Lagrangian reference. It avoids (1) fine mesh to resolve the boundary layers of particles, (2) repetitive re-meshing as particles move, 3) multi-gridding, and (4) many stiff constraints on the fluid field. Inherited the accuracy from its previous particle-resolving model for flow around spheres and spectral element methods, this model is capable of capturing drag forces of particles at moderate to high Re with the accuracy close to a direct numerical simulation. Since only one kernel function per particle is needed, this model simulates a flow of large numbers of particles with only a small extra percentage of the time for solving only the fluid phase and is one to two orders faster than a direct numerical simulation. This model provides a viable method for studying particulate flows involving so many particles that other particle-resolving methods could be cumbersome. Large-scale simulation of 100,000 to 1,000,000 sediment grains will be conducted in a wide range of Re to infer macro-scale parameters significant to coastal field application and coastal erosion.

More than 53% of the U.S. population lives in coastal regions, which are home to a wealth of natural and economic resources. Due to collective impacts of sea level rise, severe storms, and pervasive anthropogenic alterations of rivers and the coast over the past century, coastal regions are undergoing fast erosion. Mitigating coastal erosion requires improved capability of modeling sediment dynamics in rivers, estuaries and coastal seas in response to the detriment due to combined natural processes and anthropogenic activities. In addition to coastal and environmental engineering, the conjugate interactions of a fluid and large numbers of immersed particles are of vital significance to mechanical engineering, chemical engineering, combustion and petroleum processing etc. The proposed model provides an advanced simulation tool for many areas in science and engineering, and especially contributes to predicting sediment transport, mitigating coastal erosion, and improving environmental management. Knowledge in this multidisciplinary research will be used to train graduate students. The success of this project will accelerate our knowledge in computational particulate fluid flows and help better understand the mechanisms of coastal erosion. The discovery of this research will help prevent coastal erosion and protect the coastal inhabitants and infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interactions of particles with a surrounding fluid appear to be everywhere in nature, such as the polluted air flow, blood circulation, artificial drying of cocoa beans, pneumatic grain conveying system, and transport of sediment particles in riverine and coastal regions, which causes the erosion of soil and retreating of landlines in deltaic and coastal regions across the globe. Soil erosion along coastal regions and wetlands is accelerating over the past decades and posing economic and environmental threats to the local habitats and ecosystems. Transport of sediment particles of varied sizes happens at different flow regimes and water speeds. A major goal of this research is to investigate, from the computational point of view, how sediment particles are transported, what are major triggering factors, and how to predict and to reduce the rate of transport. Other goals of this project include training graduate students, enhancing intermural collaborations, and outreaching community.

In terms of the achieved intellectual merit, this project has enriched the knowledge and advanced the ability of modeling large numbers of particles in fluid-particle systems. The computational model developed in this project provides a promising method for investigating particulate flows involving so many particles that other particle-resolving methods could be relatively slower. The most prominent features of this model are the ability to significantly reduce the requirement for memory and CPU-time for large-scale particulate flows and the capability of simulating both the behavior of an individual particle and the coupled bulk motion of numerous particles and the fluid. One objective was to efficiently and accurately describe momentum coupling between a fluid and numerous particles using one fixed mesh without resorting to mesh-moving (Arbitrary Lagrangian-Eulerian) technique for dynamic simulation and formation of system matrices with time-dependent Jacobian. Another objective was to handle massive numbers of file opening, writing, updating, and closing  for numerous particles during simulation. Managing large numbers of files is quite cumbersome and reduces code performance on most Linux systems. Both objectives were accomplished. The computational model was validated and verified with other related research results and good agreement was achieved. Therefore, a viable method for simulating large-scale particulate flow systems was developed in this project.

The broader impacts in advancing the knowledge and understanding the complexity of large scale particulate flow systems have been achieved. This project developed a viable approach for fast modeling complex particulate flow involving many particles at varied Reynolds numbers with complex boundary conditions using high order methods in three dimensions. Numerical results not only provide details such as trajectory, velocity, angular velocity, etc., for individual particles in the flow, but also furnish multi-resolution details of flow fields and changes in properties regarding the bulk flow of particles and fluid. This project impact the society with a powerful alternative for better understanding complex particulate flows such as sediment transport related to soil erosion and valuable reference towards coastal and deltaic resilience. Computational intensive parts of the model have been identified, profiled, and optimized. Therefore, the overall computational efficiency, accuracy and scalability have improved noticeably. The computational overhead and CPU time at given conditions are much lower as compared with other existing particle-resolving methods and models in open literature.

The broader impacts in training graduate students and outreaching community have achieved. The PI trained a Ph.D. student in computational fluid dynamics and assisted graduate students in cross-campus learning through attending High Performance Computing Workshops and visiting a partnership institution. On the other hand, the PI outreached Bethel Christian School, a local non-profit private school in Ruston, Louisiana and assisted the director and staff members to fix smart devices, computer-related problems, and network issues, etc.

Results and discoveries from this project have been disseminated to academia and industries via conference presentations and peer-referred journal publications. Twelve invited talks and conference presentations were delivered during this project. Thirteen journal papers have been published and two more are currently under review. NSF support for the scientific, technological, and educational achievements in this project has been especially announced and acknowledged in conference presentations, invited talks, and archived publications. In addition, this project graduated one Ph.D. student in May 2015 and trained another Ph.D. student.
